articles.headline: Senate Passes Debt Limit Bill, Staving Off a Calamitous Default
articles.snippet: The final vote on Thursday night came after leaders put down a revolt by some senators who raised concerns that the debt-limit package would under-fund the Pentagon.
articles.abstract: The final vote on Thursday night came after leaders put down a revolt by some senators who raised concerns that the debt-limit package would under-fund the Pentagon.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of political impasse, tense negotiations and mounting economic anxiety, the Senate gave final approval on Thursday night to bipartisan legislation suspending the debt limit and imposing new spending caps, sending it to President Biden and ending the possibility of a calamitous government default.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Backs Employer in Suit Over Strike Losses
articles.snippet: The justices ruled that federal labor law did not block state courts from ruling on a case regarding damage caused when workers walked off the job.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled that federal labor law did not block state courts from ruling on a case regarding damage caused when workers walked off the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that federal labor law did not protect a union from potential liability for damage that arose during a strike, and that a state court should resolve questions of liability.

articles.headline: Recording of Trump Underscores Growing Evidence in Documents Case
articles.snippet: A conversation in which the former president is said to have acknowledged that he could not declassify a sensitive document could undercut a defense he has offered.
articles.abstract: A conversation in which the former president is said to have acknowledged that he could not declassify a sensitive document could undercut a defense he has offered.
articles.lead_paragraph: The revelation that federal prosecutors have a recording of former President Donald J. Trump discussing a highly sensitive document in his possession after he left office underscores the weight of the evidence that the special counsel Jack Smith is assembling as he approaches a decision about whether to bring criminal charges.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: U.S. Job Growth Remains Strong Despite Economic Clouds
articles.snippet: Employers added 339,000 workers in May, the Labor Department said, though the report also offered signs of shakiness.
articles.abstract: Employers added 339,000 workers in May, the Labor Department said, though the report also offered signs of shakiness.
articles.lead_paragraph: American employers added an unanticipated barrage of workers in May, reaffirming the labor market’s vigor.

articles.headline: She Lost Her Career, Family and Freedom. She’s Still Fighting to Change Iran.
articles.snippet: Fighting for change has cost Narges Mohammadi her career, separated her from family and deprived her of liberty. But a jail cell has not succeeded in silencing her.
articles.abstract: Fighting for change has cost Narges Mohammadi her career, separated her from family and deprived her of liberty. But a jail cell has not succeeded in silencing her.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Narges Mohammadi was just a little girl, her mother told her to never become political. The price of fighting the system in a country like Iran would be too high.

articles.headline: Apple Is Stepping Into the Metaverse. Will Anyone Care?
articles.snippet: Interest in the futuristic, immersive digital world is fading just as Apple plans to debut a virtual reality device.
articles.abstract: Interest in the futuristic, immersive digital world is fading just as Apple plans to debut a virtual reality device.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg embraced a digital world known as the metaverse when he said in November 2021 that he was changing his company’s name from Facebook to Meta.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Fed May Still ‘Skip’ June Rate Increase Even Amid Strong Hiring
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials are expected to leave rates unchanged at their June 13-14 meeting. Fresh jobs data might make the choice harder.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials are expected to leave rates unchanged at their June 13-14 meeting. Fresh jobs data might make the choice harder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials have signaled that they could hold interest rates steady at their upcoming meeting in June — pausing after 10 straight rate increases to assess whether their changes so far are sufficient to slow the economy and wrestle down rapid inflation.

articles.headline: For Turkey, Erdogan Victory Brings More Risky Economic Policy
articles.snippet: The Turkish lira has hit a new low, and analysts see few improvements ahead as re-elected President Erdogan pursues unconventional economic policies.
articles.abstract: The Turkish lira has hit a new low, and analysts see few improvements ahead as re-elected President Erdogan pursues unconventional economic policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since winning re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has publicly doubled down on his idiosyncratic economic policies.
